The Story Behind

Seagate Recovery Services

New Customer Experience

Seagate hired us to help them reinvent their online customer experience.

In early 2014, my employer, Iron-Point, received an email from a division of Seagate: “We have a new business model, we made some drastic improvements and we'd really like your help reinventing our online customer experience.”

My Role and Responsibilities

On a tight schedule, I worked with a talented team of managers, engineers and designers, and was responsible for all aspects of the user exeperience.

Because user experience was one of the three tenets for our client's new business model, I was involved early on in the project lifecycle.

I framed initial conversations with the client, prepared aspects of the brief and scope, conducted research, desiged artifacts, provided oversight after handoffs, and monitored the continual improvement of the project's KPIs post launch.

Client

Seagate manufactures more hard drives than any other business in the world. The company houses over 50,000 employees along with a number of divisions which embody several aspects of data storage.

Seagate Recovery Services, otherwise known as SRS, specializes in retrieval of missing data from most any storage device.

SRS is comprised of managers who handle strategic operations, the technicians who salvage the lost data, and a sales teams which doubles as customer support.

Customer

From photos, to film footage and spreadsheets and more, data is closely tied to human welfare. SRS understand they are in a unqiue position to offer a reassuring experience.

Their target audience is typically still in shock from discovering they've lost significant data on their hard drive or other storage media.

When customers first approach SRS emotions run high. People are looking for trust signifiers. Does it look professional? Is the pricing up front? Are the instructions self explanatory? Offering up reassurance can make or break someone in a vunerable position to hand over their hard drive.

The Business Challenge

Lower the form abandonment rate and take the pressure off phone support.

We delivered on two products to meet the challenge. Of course, there were dozens of challenges (which I'll mention below), but these two defined the success of the project.

The Form

Prospects who need to recover lost data from a failed storage device can use the online case form to send it in for an intial evaluation.

The Tracker

After paying for an evaluation fee customers are given a unique ID which they can use to log in and keep track of their case status.

Process ›

Methods › Design

Task Flows

There were dozens of conditional 'if' statements I worked with the client to define for our tracker and form.

To figure out how these would play out I first played with some concepts on paper, taking the users flow in the tracker and throwing in a wrench: 'What if their data is not recoverable, but, they want their external hard drive back?'

This type of 'if' statements helped me pen out the copy for the user interface and devise a content strategy early on for future handoff.

Wireframes

There were dozens of conditional 'if' statements I worked with the client to define for our tracker and form.

To figure out how these would play out I first played with some concepts on paper, taking the users flow in the tracker and throwing in a wrench. 'What if their data is not recoverable, but, they want their external hard drive back?'

This type of 'if' statements helped me pen out the copy for the user interface and devise a content strategy early on for future handoff.

Video Walkthrough

Creating a detailed explaination on video of the user task flow helped us win over some difficult stakeholders.

An unexpected benefit of presenting our work in a screencast first were those unanticipated 'gotchas' we could smooth over before passing it along to our Project Manager and Quality Assurance crew.

The client loved the concept and we quickly moved to refining the work in Notable.

Early Research

What was the root cause of the unusually high abandonment rates? Initial Task Analysis with users confirmed a variety of issues, both experential and technical, contributed.

The biggest culprit was a lack of pricing discloure up-front. Users had to fill out a form first before receving a price quote. In stakeholder interviews with both customer and client people spoke of 'low risk to reward ratio.'

Which lead us to our second problem: fatique. User complained about the 5-step form, with 87 unique fields, they were expected to fill out. Using metrics provided by the client we were able to confirm users left the form at the beginning or in the middle of filling it out.

And our third ranking complaint was an actual technical issue, or a poor choice of functionality, which prevented users from filling out a form field before the previous one was completed. This was made worse by the fact that the form fields were paired side-by-side and some international audiences were confused about the order they should fill the form out.

A Simpler Business Model

SRS was simplifying its business model by offering up-front pricing and faster turn-around times on repairs. This gave us the flexibility and support from the client we needed to make some radical changes to the way the form looked and behaved.

We measured time-to-completion on the legacy form and the redesign. Form completion rates went from 13m 26s to 3m 46s.

SRS contacted my employer, Iron-Point, via a referral. We’d done quite a bit of previous work for Seagate’s marketing division, assisting them with responsive email marketing templates, development, competitive analysis and research reports.

SRS wanted help salvaging their current recovery process. Their in-lab recovery form was losing them business due to poor user experience on the account of form length as well as technical issues.

Along with helping them rebuild the form, and customer journey, they also had a tracker in mind, akin to a Domino’s popular pizza delivery tracker, but for customers to track their hard drive recovery. They felt this would reduce the number of phone calls received daily by providing a clearer educational and tracking experience once a customer’s case was submitted.

Our goal was to make online data recovery easy to do. But what pushed me their was human story behind each broken drive.

SRS contacted my employer, Iron-Point, via a referral. We’d done quite a bit of previous work for Seagate’s marketing division, assisting them with responsive email marketing templates, development, competitive analysis and research reports.

SRS wanted help salvaging their current recovery process. Their in-lab recovery form was losing them business due to poor user experience on the account of form length as well as technical issues.

Along with helping them rebuild the form, and customer journey, they also had a tracker in mind, akin to a Domino’s popular pizza delivery tracker, but for customers to track their hard drive recovery. They felt this would reduce the number of phone calls received daily by providing a clearer educational and tracking experience once a customer’s case was submitted.

Project Tools

Pen & Paper I sketched and whiteboarded throughout the research and design phases.
Omnigraffle I turned concepts on paper into digital wireframes and user flows.
Notable I organized several rounds of feedback for our internal team and the client.
Screenflow I walked the client through our initial wireframes with narrated videos.
Photoshop I collaborated on the final visual design with the Creative Director.

My Role On This Project

I led the user experience for Seagate's Recovery Service e-commerce-driven case submission form and their data recovery tracker.

Discovery

Content Strategy

Without a copywriter involved in the wireframing process I helped craft a majority of the copy for the user interface. More than half of that copy has remained on the final project.

Leadership

With a background in front-end development and visual design I guided our engineers and designer on the project through their phases of the project by providing detailed design specifications along with ongoing communication as issues and questions arose.

Planning

I was involved in the earliest coversations with the client as we reviewed their Business Requirements Specifcation.

Research

Scope

I helped prepare the scope by providing feedback for our Account and Project Managers responsible for delivering the document. I worked closely with our entire senior staff to ensure all aspects of the timeline were taken under consideration and contingency plans were outlined for the client.

UX Strategy

I was involved in the earliest conversations about this project with the client and our senior team. I was responsible for leading the team to ensure the client was able to deliver a world class customer experience which would be easy to interact with on desktop, tablet and smartphones.

Aligning Customer and Business Goals

I took charge of organizing, conducting and distilling interviews with stakeholders on the client side as well as customers. I then turned my research into User Journey's, Personas and Task Flows.

Design

Scope

Aligning Customer and Business Goals

I took charge of organizing, conducting and distilling interviews with stakeholders on the client side as well as customers. I then turned my research into User Journey's, Personas and Task Flows.

First Year Results

Revenue +150% Increase
Customer +200% Engagement
Coversion +135% Rate
